thread.title: Smooth sailing for Royal Caribbean as Q2 profits rise
thread.title_full: Smooth sailing for Royal Caribbean as Q2 profits rise

title: Smooth sailing for Royal Caribbean as Q2 profits rise
text:
Save 
A strong lates market in the Caribbean and China has helped cruise giant Royal Caribbean Cruises to an improved second-quarter performance 
The world’s second-largest cruise company reported profits of $185 million versus $137.7 million for the three months to the end of June. 
Net yields – a key cruise industry metric – increased by 4.2% on an adjusted-for-currency basis. 
The company’s Double-Double campaign aims to double the company’s 2014 earnings per share by 2017 and increase return on invested capital to double digits. 
“The Double-Double introduced demanding but achievable targets for our organisation, and I am proud of our company’s focus on delivering this programme,” said Richard Fain, chairman and chief executive. 
“We continue to focus on the strength of our brands to drive these improving results.” 
The company has also upped its full-year adjusted earnings per share guidance by $0.15 to between $4.65 and $4.75.
